author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: President Biden, You Have Leverage That Can Save Lives in Gaza. Please Use It.
description: While Biden is using tougher language toward Israel, he isn’t backing that up with consequences for being ignored.
content: President Biden is sounding tougher toward Israel these days and showing more compassion for people starving in Gaza. “There are a lot of innocent people who are in trouble and dying,” Biden said. “And it’s got to stop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: How Trump Is Scrambling to Raise Cash
description: The former president is facing converging financial crunches as he and the Republican Party confront a shortfall against President Biden and the Democrats.
content: As many as three nights a week, Donald J. Trump has been hosting private dinners at Mar-a-Lago, schmoozing with some of the Republican Party’s biggest financiers as he races to address a sizable cash shortfall against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allegra Goodman
title: A Powerful Debut Novel About Rape Culture in the Workplace
description: In “Jaded,” a young lawyer searches for justice after she’s sexually assaulted by a colleague.
content: In the middle of Ela Lee’s smart, compulsively readable debut novel, “Jaded,” a human resources employee assures a young lawyer named Jade: “As you know, we take all allegations of sexual misconduct very seriously.” They’re familiar words, but what do they mean in practice? Has the #MeToo movement changed anything? “Jaded” explores one millennial’s experience as she finds out the hard way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: They Fell in Love During the Pandemic. Then Things Changed.
description: Four years after lockdowns and social distancing were implemented worldwide, four readers share their stories about their pandemic relationship regrets.
content: For some people, it wasn’t easy being single during the early days of the pandemic. Many rushed into relationships, seeking company and comfort in another person — even if the match wasn’t quite right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Rebellious Russians Stage Daring Attacks From Ukraine on Russian Soil
description: The surprise attacks, timed to Russia’s election, are meant to undermine the sense of stability in Russia and divert the country’s military resources from Ukraine.
content: Gathered in a Ukrainian farmhouse, soldiers checked their kits: rifles, machine guns, grenade launchers, spare batteries for radios, red and white flashlights, all that would be needed for a stealthy and daring night assault across the border into Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaina Feinberg and Julia Rothman
title: I Asked My Mom if She Was Prepared to Die
description: Then I talked to some end-of-life experts. Here’s what I found out.
content: Recently, I had the following conversation with my 82-year-old mother, Mary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: A Shooter’s Parents Were Convicted of Manslaughter. What Happens Next?
description: The prosecution of James and Jennifer Crumbley could affect the courts and parenting in the wake of the worst school shooting in Michigan history.
content: When the prosecutor Karen McDonald decided to press criminal charges against the parents of the teenager who carried out the deadliest school shooting in Michigan’s history, even some members of her own staff expressed doubts, fearing the case was too ambitious to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Andrew E. Kramer, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn and Oleg Matsnev
title: In Occupied Ukraine, Casting a Vote (for Putin) as Armed Soldiers Watch
description: Russia is holding a presidential vote in the occupied regions of Ukraine to try to legitimize its rule there, expose dissenters and present a veneer of democracy.
content: A new sign went up a few miles from the front line recently on the main billboard of an occupied town in Ukraine’s Luhansk region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After a Drought, Light Hauls and Heavy Hearts
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 16, 2024.
content: “It should be on the flag, you know what I’m saying?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: In Search of Spring
description: For those of us who’ve been white-knuckling our way through winter, the new season can’t arrive soon enough.
content: When does spring begin? For some, it’s the second Sunday in March, when we turn our clocks forward by an hour in the United States. For others, it’s when they first realize they’ve finished dinner and it’s still light out, or when the first crocuses poke up through the snow. Is it when you can go outside without a jacket and not feel a chill? When you pack away the down bedding and down jackets for another year? In the Northern Hemisphere, the vernal equinox will officially take place this Tuesday, March 19, at 11:06 p.m. Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: United Airlines Flight Arrives at Oregon Airport Missing an External Panel
description: No one realized that the panel from the plane, a Boeing 737-800, was missing until it had landed safely, the airline said.
content: A United Airlines flight that took off on Friday morning from San Francisco International Airport landed in Oregon missing an external panel, the Federal Aviation Administration said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Was He Secretly Working for China? This Is What He Told Us.
description: Di Sanh Duong openly said that some people might mistake him for a Chinese spy, but he maintained that he never did anything to hurt Australia.
content: Not long after we first met, the man said that if Australia was looking for Chinese spies, he was just the type of person they would be looking at — but the authorities would never “dare say I’m Chinese intelligence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Lauren Hirsch
title: What Must Nelson Peltz Do to Get Some Respect?
description: The longtime corporate agitator feels misunderstood. Maybe his fight with Disney could change that.
content: At age 81, with over four decades of dealmaking and corporate cage-rattling under his belt, Nelson Peltz would seem to have pretty much everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: You’re Not Being Gaslit, Says a New Book. (Or Are You?)
description: “On Gaslighting,” by the philosophy professor Kate Abramson, explores the psychological phenomenon behind the hashtags.
content: Don’t be so sensitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Colorado Man Died From Venomous Gila Monster Bite, Autopsy Confirms
description: The rare fatality happened after the man endured a four-minute-long bite from the lizard to his right hand in February, records show.
content: An autopsy report revealed that a pet Gila monster’s venomous bite contributed to a Colorado man’s death in February in what an expert described as “an incredibly rare” fatality caused by one of the desert lizards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen and Vishakha Darbha
title: America Owes a Historical Debt to Haiti
description: The United States is complicit in the nation’s political chaos. It’s time to change that.
content: Despite the violence and political turmoil in Haiti, New York Times Opinion columnist Lydia Polgreen argues that this might be the tipping point that finally brings peace to that island nation. U.S. interference in Haiti has long been criticized, and in this audio essay, she says we finally have a chance to repair the damage we’ve done and help set the country back on a course toward dignity and democracy: “Just because there is this long history of failure doesn’t mean that success is not possible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke
title: Hitting the Slopes With a Wild, and Skilled, ‘old’ Bunch
description: Skiers in their 70s, 80s and 90s aren’t letting age stop them from doing what they love. One reporter hitched a ride on their chairlift — and tried to keep up.
content: A chairlift might just be the best place for a reporter to conduct an interview: It offers uninterrupted minutes of distraction-free conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: For Irish L.G.B.T.Q. New Yorkers, It’s Been a Long Way to Staten Island
description: Activists like Brendan Fay have campaigned for decades to make St. Patrick’s Day festivities open to L.G.B.T.Q. groups. A new parade in Staten Island on Sunday is their final achievement.
content: This year, for the first time, every New York City borough will host a St. Patrick’s Day Parade that allows L.G.B.T.Q. groups, bringing a decades-long conflict to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Bill’s Progress Slows in the Senate
description: Legislation to force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or have it banned in the United States sailed through the House, but the Senate has no plans to move hastily.
content: After a bill that would force TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a nationwide ban sailed through the House at breakneck speed this week, its progress has slowed in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Maddie McGarvey
title: Republican Senate Slugfest in Ohio Fuels Jitters About Trump’s Candidate
description: The former president will appear alongside Bernie Moreno on Saturday, one potential sign that Mr. Moreno could use an 11th-hour assist.
content: With just days to go before the election, the three-way Republican Senate primary in Ohio has turned into a food fight, fueling concerns about former President Donald J. Trump’s favored candidate, Bernie Moreno.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Americans Invested Billions in Chinese Companies. Now Their Money Is Stuck.
description: TikTok’s turn in geopolitical cross hairs highlights the narrowing paths to liquidity for investments in Chinese companies.
content: When investors talk about “zombie” companies, they’re usually referring to distressed start-ups that are hobbling along, unable to grow and unlikely to ever return the money they’ve raised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Barrett
title: Covid Precautions Are Still With Us. Just Look Down.
description: Tattered vestiges of the pandemic serve as a reminder of a scary and surreal time.
content: In the early days of the Covid pandemic, public health experts announced that maintaining a distance of six feet between yourself and other people would help prevent the spread of the virus. Seemingly overnight, stickers began to appear on the floors of grocery stores, post offices, pharmacies, and other public spaces, as well as the sidewalks in front of them. Placed six feet apart, they helped us navigate the directive to distance ourselves, indicating where we should stand to be safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Kellyanne Conway Has Some Weak Advice for Her Party
description: Voters’ concerns over abortion rights won’t be easy to avoid.
content: It is beyond obvious at this point that abortion is the Achilles’ heel of the Republican Party. The prospect of a national abortion ban almost certainly helped Democrats stave off a red wave in the 2022 midterm elections, and assisted them the following year in both statewide and state legislative races in Virginia and Kentucky. The prospect of abortion bans has also pushed voters in states such as Ohio and Michigan to approve sweeping affirmations of reproductive freedom in their respective state constitutions. And abortion looms over the 2024 race, as well; Democrats will spend countless millions to tell Americans that a vote for Trump, or any Republican on the ballot, is a vote for a national abortion ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Irish Cream Coffee Cake
description: Four words, a lot of weekend baking delight.
content: I always get a kick from cooking with booze. “Shots!” I’ll announce to nobody in particular as I add the tequila for salted margarita bars. And, without fail, “one for you, one for me” as I deglaze my skillet with a glass of white wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Bilal Shbair and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: ‘Practically Fasting for Months’: Gazans Struggle to Celebrate Ramadan
description: A time of religious devotion, dawn-to-dusk fasting and charity is instead a daily struggle for survival.
content: Every night during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, the man would come along Rawoand Altatar’s street, banging on his drum and calling out to the faithful to wake them up for suhoor, the predawn meal. His nightly mission used to be lit up by Ramadan lamps and twinkling decorations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Unprepared for What Has Already Happened
description: Stories of people waking up to a suddenly changed world.
content: Stories of people waking up to the fact that the world has suddenly changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Luchette
title: A Sophomore Novel About a Laid-Off Librarian With Obsessive Tendencies
description: In “Bad Animals,” Sarah Braunstein asks who has the right to tell a story — and whether it’s possible to get pulled into one against your will.
content: When she loses her job at a library in a small Maine town, Maeve, the middle-aged protagonist of Sarah Braunstein’s bracing second novel, “Bad Animals,” signs up for a free hour with a life coach. “I see that you’ve lived for others for a long time,” the woman tells her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: When Medicaid Comes After the Family Home
description: Federal law requires states to seek reimbursement from the assets, usually homes, of people who died after receiving benefits for long-term care.
content: The letter came from the state department of human services in July 2021. It expressed condolences for the loss of the recipient’s mother, who had died a few weeks earlier at 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Took the Lead?
description: Carly Schuna’s Saturday debut gets the day started off right.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the third Times crossword and first Saturday grid from Carly Schuna, and it’s spot on. There’s one zingy term after another, and the whole thing is imbued with great personality. I knew a lot of the trivia and picked up on the pet and pop culture references. “Quick solve,” I thought — and then I hit the wall in the southeast corner, falling for three misdirections. Ultimately, the difficulty level today is appropriate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Rachel Bujalski
title: Driving With Mr. Gil: A Retiree Teaches Afghan Women the Rules of the Road
description: Local lore says that one 82-year-old professor has probably taught more Afghan women drivers in a California town than there are in all Afghanistan. For them, it’s not about empowerment; it’s for groceries.
content: Bibifatima Akhundzada wove a white Chevy Spark through downtown Modesto, Calif., on a recent morning, practicing turns, braking and navigating intersections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Now Featured at Beauty Stores: Teens Driven by Social Media
description: Sephora has emerged as a retailer of choice among teenagers and preadolescents. Its new chief executive sees both a challenge and an opportunity.
content: Impelled in large part by TikTok to seek beauty products meant for adults, younger customers — teenagers and even preadolescents — are proving to be a mixed blessing for retailers like Sephora and Ulta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Oshinsky
title: Where Did Baseball Come of Age? Not Where You Might Think.
description: In his book “The New York Game,” Kevin Baker tells the origin story of the sport we know today.
content: New York City is enduring a professional sports drought of epic proportions. Football, as currently played by the Giants and Jets, is essentially over by Thanksgiving, with both clubs eliminated from playoff contention. None of New York’s three regional hockey teams has hoisted the Stanley Cup in the past 20 years, and basketball is drier still. The Knicks last won an N.B.A. championship in 1973, when the embattled Richard Nixon was president. The Brooklyn Nets, a haven for feuding superstars, have yet to reach the finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: It’s a Visual Effects Extravaganza, but There’s Not an Explosion in Sight
description: Though blockbusters are synonymous with computer imagery, dramas and art-house films rely extensively on tech magic, too. Don’t be fooled by the naturalism.
content: A woman crosses a bustling street at night. Cars pass noisily. A streetcar cruises by. Behind her, we see twinkling streetlights, a cinema marquee, towering neon signs. It rained earlier; the roads are still wet. It’s Mexico City in the early 1970s, and it feels vibrantly alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
title: Standing Up to China, Philippine Leader Courts New Network of Partners
description: Escalating tensions in the South China Sea, President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. says, are not only a regional issue, but a global one.
content: With China aggressively asserting its claims on the South China Sea, President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines spent his first year on the job beefing up Manila’s alliance with its oldest ally, the United States. Now he is shoring up support from a wider and new network of partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Do I Have to Allow the Landlord to Do Building Repairs in My Apartment?
description: The law permits landlords to make upgrades in rent-stabilized units, but that doesn’t mean your rent has to go up.
content: Q: I am a senior citizen and have lived for almost 50 years in a small building in Queens. My apartment is the only rent-stabilized unit in the building. The landlord is installing a new heating system in the building, which will involve major work in my apartment to install new pipes. The current system works well, and it appears the installation of a new system is mainly to bring in more rent for the landlord. Do I have to allow this work in my unit? Will my rent increase once the new heating system is functioning?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Magdalene J. Taylor
title: It’s Not You: Dating Apps Are Getting Worse
description: Hinge, Tinder, Bumble: They used to be free and maybe too good to be true. Now paid versions and fatigue are making dating apps worse — and expensive.
content: “The golden age of dating apps is over,” a friend told me at a bar on Super Bowl Sunday. As we waited for our drinks, she and another friend swiped through Bumble and Hinge, hunting for new faces and likes. Across the bar were two young men: phones out, apps open, clearly doing the exact same thing. Never did the duos meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: A Friendly Reminder: A.I. Work Isn’t Yours
description: Using A.I. without acknowledging it is a problem that workplaces need to address.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Miguel Soffia and John Bartlett
title: Chile’s Deadliest Wildfire Is Said to Have Been Made Worse by a Lack of Water
description: Poor water pressure and dry hydrants posed major obstacles to fighting the February fire that killed scores of people along the country’s Pacific Coast.
content: As a fast-moving wildfire swept through the cities of Viña del Mar and Quilpué on Chile’s Pacific Coast last month, flames engulfed residents on the street, destroyed homes and overwhelmed the utility grid. Power shut off, communications went down and not enough water reached a critical line of defense: the fire hydrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau Wonders About the Past 2 Million Years
description: The “Game of Thrones” actor, now hosting a documentary series on climate change, is captivated by genetics research, algorithms and tiny art.
content: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau wants people to step away from the abyss when it comes to climate action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: The Tinge of Stained Glass
description: In the old New York Times headquarters, stained-glass panels adorned the editorial offices — and colored the place in more ways than one.
content: “The New York Times is a university — one of the greatest universities in the world — with its doors open to whoso runs and reads at a tuition fee of two cents a day,” The Times declared in 1924 in a booklet called, “The Making of a Great Newspaper.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Health Misinformation Is Evolving. Here’s How to Spot It.
description: Experts offer tips for combating false medical claims in your own circles.
content: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Monday in a case that involves the Biden administration’s efforts to communicate with social media sites about posts officials believed made false or misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines and the pandemic. While the case primarily focuses on a debate around free speech, it also spotlights the potential harms of medical misinformation — which experts say has become increasingly complex and difficult to identify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk, Gaya Gupta and Nicholas Fandos
title: First Sea-Borne Aid Reaches Gaza Amid Fears About Security and Malnutrition
description: The 200 tons of food provided by a celebrity chef’s charity arrived as UNICEF said rising numbers of children in Gaza were facing food deprivation.
content: The first shipment of aid to reach Gaza by sea in almost two decades was fully unloaded on Saturday on a makeshift jetty in the Mediterranean, marking a milestone in a venture that Western officials hope will ease the enclave’s worsening food deprivation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Landline Users Remain Proudly ‘Old-Fashioned’ in the Digital Age
description: Traditional phones may seem like relics in the iPhone era, but a recent AT&T cellular service outage had some landline lovers extolling their virtues.
content: When millions of AT&T customers across the country briefly lost their cellphone service last month, Francella Jackson, 61, of Fairview Heights, Ill., said she picked up her well-worn Southwestern Bell push-button landline phone and called her friends “just so we could laugh at the people who could not use their phones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia Wanted to Catch Chinese Spies. Is This Really Whom It Had in Mind?
description: The first case tried under Australia’s foreign interference laws has raised tough questions about the breadth of the regulations.
content: The police officers asked the man what he meant when he said that involving an Australian government minister in a charity event could benefit “us Chinese.” Was he talking about mainland China and the Chinese Communist Party, or the local Australian Chinese community? Depending on the answer, he faced up to 10 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Larry H. Parker, an Injury Lawyer Who Promised to ‘Fight for You,’ Dies at 75
description: In the Los Angeles area, Mr. Parker was a common sight on billboards and television commercials in which he promised to stand up to faceless insurance companies.
content: Larry H. Parker, an accident and personal injury lawyer whose television commercials promised he’d “fight for you” and became staples in living rooms across Los Angeles, died on March 6 in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: U.N. Documents More Than Two Dozen Attacks on Gazans Waiting for Aid Since January
description: The United Nations human rights office has not blamed any side for the attacks, including one on Thursday that Gazan health officials say killed 20.
content: The United Nations human rights office has documented more than two dozen attacks on Gazans waiting for desperately needed aid since January, with hunger spreading as a result of Israel’s near complete siege, preventing most food and water from entering the tiny enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Share of Democratic Registrations Is Declining, but What Does It Mean?
description: Virtually every group of voters under 70 has become less likely to register as Democrats compared with Republicans since 2019.
content: Newly registered voters, who are disproportionately young and nonwhite, have tended to lean Democratic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Fani Willis Hangs Onto Trump Case, but More Turbulence Lies Ahead
description: A fresh array of problems are in store for Ms. Willis and her prosecution of Donald Trump, one of the most significant state criminal cases in American history.
content: After revelations of Fani T. Willis’s romance with a subordinate sent the Georgia criminal case against Donald J. Trump down a two-month detour worthy of a soap opera, a judge’s ruling on Friday resolved a major cliffhanger. Ms. Willis could continue prosecuting the case, so long as her ex-boyfriend withdrew from it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Mike Lynch, Former U.K. Tech Mogul, Faces the Trial of His Life
description: A criminal trial is set to begin for Mr. Lynch, the founder of the software company Autonomy, which was sold to Hewlett-Packard in 2011 and later accused of being a fraud.
content: Every morning in his townhouse in the tony San Francisco neighborhood of Pacific Heights, the man once referred to as Britain’s Bill Gates gets to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Does Everyone Want to Be on the ‘Mommy Track’?
description: More people are rejecting the false binary of remote work vs. the corporate ladder.
content: When I caught up recently with Liz Koelsch, one of the moms that my friend Jessica Bennett profiled for our 2021 “primal scream” project — a look at motherhood during the pandemic’s peak — a lot had changed in her life. In the four years since Covid-19 was declared a national emergency, Koelsch, who was a single mom when we first met her, got married to a great guy. She completed an associate degree in paralegal studies. And she’s finally happy at work because she has moved to a job that is mostly remote and her boss is “all about time flexibility.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal and Glenn Thrush
title: Boeing Criminal Inquiry Expands With Subpoenas and Grand Jury
description: The Justice Department, which is investigating the blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines flight, is using a recently convened grand jury in Seattle.
content: The Justice Department is sending subpoenas and using a recently convened grand jury in Seattle as it widens a criminal investigation into the door plug that blew off a Boeing 737 Max 9 jetliner in January, a person familiar with the matter said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: 3 People Fatally Shot in Two Pennsylvania Township Homes, Police Say
description: A manhunt led the police to Trenton, N.J., where the gunman was taken into custody Saturday evening.
content: Three people were fatally shot on Saturday morning at two separate residences in Falls Township in Pennsylvania, according to the authorities, who said the gunman fled and was tracked to Trenton, N.J., where he eventually surrendered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Ankle Monitors and Curfews: Inside Biden’s New Tracking System for Migrant Families
description: The goal of the program is to keep people from skipping out on their asylum hearings, joining the millions of undocumented people who stay in the country indefinitely.
content: On a recent evening in California, a woman named Sandra was at a birthday party with her 15-year-old son when she glanced at the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 16, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 16, 2024.
content: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about President Biden’s campaign visit to Milwaukee misstated the number of times Mr. Biden has traveled to Wisconsin during his presidency. As the article correctly noted, this was the president’s ninth visit to the state, not his eighth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Part-Time Employees: The Plight of the Mistreated
description: Readers discuss a novelist’s guest essay about how the retailers benefit but the workers struggle.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Delury
title: A Solution on North Korea Is There, if Biden Will Only Grasp It
description: Biden should act to prevent North Korea from adding to the list of U.S. headaches.
content: How do you solve a problem like North Korea?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Examining Trump’s Alternate Reality Pitch
description: The war in Ukraine. Hamas’s attack on Israel. Inflation. The former president has insisted that none would have occurred if he had remained in office after 2020.
content: Aside from falsely insisting that he did not lose the 2020 election, former President Donald J. Trump has peddled a related set of theories centered on one question: What would the world have looked like had he stayed in office?
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Novels to Make You Sweat and Shiver
description: A love affair between jurors; reclaiming a classic.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi and Debra Kamin
title: Five Ways Buying and Selling a House Could Change
description: The National Association of Realtors has agreed to change its policies to settle several lawsuits brought by home sellers — a move that could reduce commissions.
content: A settlement reached this week threatens to strike a blow to an established standard of residential real estate: the 6 percent sales commission. It also will change who pays it. The deal, reached after a yearslong court battle initially brought by a group of home sellers in Missouri, calls for the powerful National Association of Realtors, which has long regulated the way U.S. homes are sold, to amend its rules on how Realtors for sellers and buyers are compensated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Does Having a Gun Make a Person Suspicious? Courts Aren’t Sure Now.
description: A U.S. Supreme Court ruling that could allow more New Yorkers to carry guns is raising thorny questions and has jeopardized at least one case so far.
content: It was 2:30 a.m. on Valentine’s Day last year when a detective watching a live camera feed from a major Queens thoroughfare spotted a man in a minivan who appeared to be holding a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: When Manahahtáanung Became European
description: The New-York Historical Society acknowledges a notorious purchase 400 years ago — and lets the Lenape tell their side: “We are still here.”
content: Entering the New-York Historical Society from Central Park West, all visitors come upon a section of wampum belt and the kind of statement that in the last several years has become standard fare at cultural institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: India’s 2024 General Election: What to Know
description: India’s general elections will determine the political direction of the world’s most populous nation for the next five years.
content: India is holding its multiphase general elections from April 19 to June 1, in a vote that will determine the political direction of the world’s most populous nation for the next five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Nicholas Fandos
title: Menendez Leaves Re-Election Plans Murky, But Dormant Campaign Gives Hints
description: Senator Robert Menendez, facing federal bribery charges, has been coy about his plans. But running for office might offer advantages that have little to do with winning another term.
content: Plagued by legal trouble and abandoned by his allies, Senator Robert Menendez has made clear what he will not do: quit before his term is over in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: After Another Subway Shooting, New York Wrestles With Question of Safety
description: Even with the National Guard patrolling the system, some New Yorkers say they don’t feel secure, particularly after the subway shooting in Brooklyn on Thursday. Others remain unfazed.
content: The subway crime that Jimmy Sumampow had been hearing about in recent years — as well as his own experience — had already led him to make plans to leave New York City. Then, on Friday, he saw a video online of the shooting on an A train this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Alan Feuer, William K. Rashbaum and Maggie Haberman
title: Stalling: A Time-Tested Legal Strategy That Keeps Working for Trump
description: A delay in the former president’s impending Manhattan trial date was just the latest example of his ability to bend his busy court calendar in his favor.
content: The schedule seemed stacked against Donald J. Trump: four criminal trials in four cities, all in the same year he is running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: All Over the Map
description: Simeon Seigel’s Sunday debut lays out an awe-inspiring itinerary.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke and Kate Russell
title: These Skiers Are Still Chasing Powder in Their 80s and 90s
description: For the Wild old Bunch of Alta, Utah, getting older means more time for the mountain. And anyone over 80 skis free.
content: It was a bluebird morning at the Alta Ski Area and Carol Bowling, 76, was looking for fresh powder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Authorities Seize Alligator Being Held Illegally in Home Near Buffalo
description: The alligator, Albert Edward, had been with his owner for 34 years.
content: The alligator’s name was Albert Edward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Financial Crisis May Jeopardize Local News in Most of Atlantic Canada
description: The main lender for SaltWire, which owns most of the region’s legacy newspapers outside New Brunswick, has moved to dissolve the publisher.
content: Local news outlets have, of course, been in trouble in Canada and around the world for years. But now a lender has asked a Halifax court to dissolve the two companies that jointly own most of the newspapers in Atlantic Canada outside New Brunswick. And that has opened up the possibility that the region may end up without any legacy news outlets aside from broadcasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: For Ytasha Womack, the Afrofuture Is Now
description: The writer and filmmaker discusses the blend of theoretical cosmology and Black culture in Chicago’s newest planetarium show.
content: On Feb. 17, the Adler Planetarium in Chicago unveiled a new sky show called “Niyah and the Multiverse,” a blend of theoretical cosmology, Black culture and imagination. And as with many things Afrofuturistic, Ytasha Womack’s fingerprints are all over it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: A Reporter With a Fear of Snakes Joins a Snake Catcher
description: To write about the increase in snake encounters in Australia, a journalist had to get hands-on with the slithering reptiles.
content: The carpet python in the car didn’t seem angry, but it was certainly curious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Miller
title: How a Marathoner and Sommelier Spends His Sundays
description: Yannick Benjamin has been training for the wheelchair race at the New York City Half Marathon, meditating and taking breaks to enjoy (but not critique) wine with his wife.
content: In New York wine industry circles, Yannick Benjamin is known as one of the top sommeliers. He learned his trade as a young man at places like Jean-Georges and Le Cirque. His work in hospitality took on a new meaning in 2003, when he was in a car accident at age 25 and became paralyzed from the waist down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Catherine Porter
title: In Paris, the Olympics Clean Up Their Act
description: Organizers of the Games promise to slash greenhouse gas emissions by re-using historic buildings, adding bike lanes, even putting solar panels on the Seine. Will it work?
content: How do you produce a global sporting event, with millions of people swooping down on one city, in the age of global warming?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Miguel Soffia and Kristen Williamson
title: ‘No Water in the Hydrants’: Communities Left Defenseless Against Chile’s Deadliest Wildfire
description: Weeks after Chile’s deadliest wildfire, some firefighters and residents said a lack of water to fire hydrants had hampered efforts to combat the inferno that destroyed thousands of homes and killed 134.
content: Weeks after Chile’s deadliest wildfire, some firefighters and residents said a lack of water to fire hydrants had hampered efforts to combat the inferno that destroyed thousands of homes and killed 134.
source.name: The New York Times
